title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the island that is in the earliest stage of succession as Island E.
The response identifies the island that is in the earliest stage of succession as Island E.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why Island D has lower biodiversity than Island A, such as any of the following:

· Island D is smaller than Island A, so it will have fewer habitats and thus fewer species.

· Island D is farther from the mainland than Island A, so Island D will have a lower immigration rate/be able to support fewer species/have a higher extinction rate.

The response explains why Island D has lower biodiversity than Island A, such as one of the following:

· Island D is smaller than Island A, so it will have fewer habitats and thus fewer species.

· Island D is farther from the mainland than Island A, so Island D will have a lower immigration rate/be able to support fewer species/have a higher extinction rate.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe why an herbivore would be well suited to survive on Island C, such as any of the following:

· Herbivores are primary consumers that eat plants/producers, which are present on Island C.

· Grasses and shrubs are found on Island C so there would be a food source for an herbivore on Island C.

· There are fewer predators of herbivores present among the animal species on Island C, so the herbivore would be less likely to be prey.

The response describes why an herbivore would be well suited to survive on Island C, such as one of the following:

· Herbivores are primary consumers that eat plants/producers, which are present on Island C.

· Grasses and shrubs are found on Island C so there would be a food source for an herbivore on Island C.

· There are fewer predators of herbivores present among the animal species on Island C, so the herbivore would be less likely to be prey.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify and does not describe the type of plate boundary between Plate 1 and Plate 2, such as the following:

· A convergent boundary is shown between Plate 1 and Plate 2 because the plates are moving toward each other/pushing against each other.

The response identifies and describes the type of plate boundary between Plate 1 and Plate 2, such as the following:

· A convergent boundary is shown between Plate 1 and Plate 2 because the plates are moving toward each other/pushing against each other.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the geologist’s assertion that Island A is the oldest island in the group of islands off the coast of the mainland, such as any of the following:

· The geologist’s assertion is supported based on the diagram because the islands were likely formed as Plate 2 moved over the stationary hot spot. Island A is the farthest from the hot spot, so it was likely the first island that was formed.

· Established forests also suggest Island A is in a later successional stage than the other islands indicating it is older than the other islands supporting the geologist’s assertion.

The response makes a claim using evidence that supports or refutes the geologist’s assertion that Island A is the oldest island in the group of islands off the coast of the mainland, such as one of the following:

· The geologist’s assertion is supported based on the diagram because the islands were likely formed as Plate 2 moved over the stationary hot spot. Island A is the farthest from the hot spot, so it was likely the first island that was formed.

· Established forests also suggest Island A is in a later successional stage than the other islands indicating it is older than the other islands supporting the geologist’s assertion.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the control terrarium for the investigation as Terrarium 1.
The response identifies the control terrarium for the investigation as Terrarium 1.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one biotic modification that could be made to the investigation that could alter the results, such as any of the following:

· Add more/less snails

· Add more/less grass seeds

· Add a different type of plant

· Use a variety of plants

· Use different soils with different soil organisms

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the role of earthworms in the cycling of nitrogen in the terrariums, such as any of the following:

· Earthworms release nitrogenous wastes in the soil. These wastes can be broken down by soil microbes or taken up by plants.

· Earthworms mechanically break down organic matter that can more easily be decomposed by soil microbes that release nitrogen (ammonia/ammonifiers).

· Decomposers, like earthworms, breakdown dead organic matter and release ammonia or nitrate.

· When earthworms die, they are a source of organic nitrogen for soil bacteria/fungi/decomposers.

The response describes the role of earthworms in the cycling of nitrogen in the terrariums, such as one of the following:

· Earthworms release nitrogenous wastes in the soil. These wastes can be broken down by soil microbes or taken up by plants.

· Earthworms mechanically break down organic matter that can more easily be decomposed by soil microbes that release nitrogen (ammonia/ammonifiers).

· Decomposers, like earthworms, breakdown dead organic matter and release ammonia or nitrate.

· When earthworms die, they are a source of organic nitrogen for soil bacteria/fungi/decomposers.

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the role of the snail in the cycling of carbon in the terrariums, such as any of the following:

· The snail takes in carbon through consumption; they eat plant tissues that contain carbon/organic compounds.

· During cellular respiration, snails break down organic compounds/sugars and release carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

· During decomposition, the snail tissue is broken down and the stored organic material is converted to carbon dioxide.

· Snail shells store carbon for longer periods of time.

The response describes the role of the snail in the cycling of carbon in the terrariums, such as one of the following:

· The snail takes in carbon through consumption; they eat plant tissues that contain carbon/organic compounds.

· During cellular respiration, snails break down organic compounds/sugars and release carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

· During decomposition, the snail tissue is broken down and the stored organic material is converted to carbon dioxide.

· Snail shells store carbon for longer periods of time.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the number of kilocalories measured in the plants in the terrarium is greater than the number of kilocalories available to the snail or to the earthworm, such as any of the following:

· The transfer of energy from one trophic level to the next is not 100% efficient. Only a small part of the energy moves from one level to the next.

· The plant uses some energy for survival/growth/reproduction and some energy is lost as heat energy and cannot be passed on.

· Only a small portion of the energy in the previous trophic level will be available to the next trophic level based on the 10% rule.

The response explains why the number of kilocalories measured in the plants in the terrarium is greater than the number of kilocalories available to the snail or to the earthworm, such as one of the following:

· The transfer of energy from one trophic level to the next is not 100% efficient. Only a small part of the energy moves from one level to the next.

· The plant uses some energy for survival/growth/reproduction and some energy is lost as heat energy and cannot be passed on.

· Only a small portion of the energy in the previous trophic level will be available to the next trophic level based on the 10% rule.
